title: RL32589
content: The Federal Communications Commission (FCC) is an independent federal agency established by the Communications Act of 1934. It regulates interstate and international communications by radio, television, wire, satellite, and cable. The FCC's mission is to ensure non-discriminatory access to communication services. The 1934 Act outlines the commission's powers and structure, with five appointed members. The FCC, established in 1934, is governed by five commissioners appointed by the President and approved by the Senate for five-year terms. Title II covers common carrier regulation, Title III focuses on broadcast station requirements, and Title IV includes procedural and administrative provisions. The FCC's jurisdiction is limited to interstate and international common carriers. Title III of the 1934 Act covers broadcast station requirements, while Title IV includes procedural and administrative provisions. The FCC is governed by five commissioners appointed by the President for five-year terms, with one designated as chairperson. Three commissioners may be from the same political party as the President, and none can have a financial interest in commission-related business. The FCC is governed by five commissioners appointed by the President for five-year terms, with one designated as chairperson. Ajit Pai is the current Chair, along with Michael O'Rielly, Brendan Carr, Jessica Rosenworcel, and Geoffrey Starks as commissioners. The FCC's day-to-day functions are carried out by 7 bureaus and 10 offices, with the current basic structure established in 2002 to better reflect the industries it regulates. The Consumer and Governmental Affairs Bureau serves as the public face of the Commission and maintains partnerships with state, local, and tribal governments. The Disability Rights Office provides expert advice on accessibility for persons with disabilities. The Enforcement Bureau enforces the Communications Act and the FCC's rules, protecting consumers, ensuring efficient use of spectrum, promoting competition, and resolving disputes. The International Bureau administers the FCC's international telecommunications and satellite programs, promoting pro-competitive policies abroad and advocating U.S. interests in international communications. The Media Bureau recommends, develops, and administers policy and licensing programs for electronic media. The Public Safety and Homeland Security Bureau develops and implements policies to strengthen public safety communications, homeland security, national security, emergency management, and network reliability in the United States and its territories. This includes rulemaking proceedings to improve public safety spectrum use, enhance 911 systems, and prioritize communications during crises. The Bureau also maintains 24/7 operations and promotes Commission preparedness for emergencies and disasters. The Wireless Telecommunications Bureau oversees wireless telecommunications programs and policies in the US, including licensing and regulatory functions for services like cellular, paging, and mobile broadband. The Wireline Competition Bureau focuses on policies for fixed broadband and telephone landlines, promoting widespread availability of these services and managing the Universal Service Fund. The FCC is divided into various bureaus and offices, including Administrative Law Judges who preside over hearings, Communications Business Opportunities promoting competition, Economics and Analytics for economic analysis and auctions, and Engineering and Technology advising on technical matters. In 2019, the Office of Strategic Planning and Policy Analysis was replaced by the Office of Economics and Analytics. The FCC is divided into bureaus and offices such as Engineering and Technology, General Counsel, Inspector General, Legislative Affairs, Managing Director, Media Relations, and Workplace Diversity to handle technical, legal, audit, legislative, administrative, media, and diversity matters. The FCC Secretary ensures integrity in FCC operations. The FCC Secretary oversees the integrity of FCC records, manages document filing systems, and provides legal notice of FCC decisions. The current FCC Strategic Plan aims to close the digital divide by making broadband more accessible and affordable, and promoting innovation in the communications market. The FCC's key priorities include promoting entrepreneurship, expanding economic opportunity, and protecting consumers and public safety. They plan to combat robocalls, make communications accessible for people with disabilities, and reform their processes for transparency and accountability. The FCC aims to modernize operations, improve decision-making, and reduce regulatory burdens. Performance objectives are set for each strategic goal. Commission management annually sets targets and measures for performance goals, published in the FCC's Performance Plan and submitted with the annual budget request to Congress. Results are detailed in the FCC's Annual Performance Report each February, along with a Summary of Performance and Financial Results. Funding for the FCC has been through the House and Senate Financial Services and General Government appropriations bill since the 110th Congress. Regulatory fees are collected annually to offset agency costs. The FCC collects regulatory fees annually to fund its operations, derived from license holders and certain entities. These fees, known as "Section (9) fees," do not apply to certain non-commercial entities. The FCC reviews and adjusts the fees each year based on changes in its appropriation. A hearing on the FY2020 FCC budget addressed various issues such as 5G deployment, merger reviews, robocalls, and net neutrality. The agency has wide latitude to revise its interpretation of the public interest standard, leading to significant changes in how it regulates the broadcast and telecommunications industries over time. Changes in FCC leadership have influenced the agency's strategic goals, resulting in the repeal of net neutrality rules in 2017 and structural changes in 2019. The FCC's strategic goals are outlined in its quadrennial Strategic Plan, reflecting the evolving priorities of the commission. Chairman Wheeler's strategic goals in the FY2015-FY2018 plan focused on protecting and benefiting the public through regulation, emphasizing the rights of users and responsibilities of network providers. In contrast, Chairman Pai's goals in the FY2018-FY2022 plan also aim to protect and benefit the public, but with a different approach. Chairman Pai's regulatory philosophy focuses on promoting market incentives and efficiency, aiming to reduce regulatory burdens and promote entrepreneurship. This approach is evident in the strategic goals of the FCC, particularly in the context of the net neutrality debate. Chairman Pai's regulatory philosophy contrasts with that of Chairman Wheeler, emphasizing market incentives and efficiency over strict regulations. The 2015 Open Internet Order and the 2017 Order illustrate this difference in approach to net neutrality. The FCC's 2017 Restoring Internet Freedom Order has sparked debate over net neutrality laws. In January 2019, the FCC voted to replace the Office of Strategic Planning and Policy Analysis with a new Office of Economics and Analytics, a move approved along party lines. The FCC established the Office of Economics and Analytics to enhance economic analysis in policy making, improve auction processes, and implement data practices. This aligns with the goal of modernizing operations, reducing regulatory burdens, and adapting to market realities.
